slides.title: Welcome to Geology
slides.content:
# Introduction to Geology

Welcome to **Geology** - the study of Earth!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Earth's Structure** - Layers of our planet
- **Plate Tectonics** - Moving continents
- **Rocks and Minerals** - Earth's building blocks
- **Geological Processes** - Volcanoes, earthquakes

> **Fun Fact:** Earth is about 4.54 billion years old!

slides.title: Earth's Structure
slides.content:
# Earth's Structure

## Layers:

| Layer | Depth | Composition |
|-------|-------|-------------|
| Crust | 0-70 km | Silicate rocks |
| Mantle | 70-2900 km | Silicates, semi-solid |
| Outer Core | 2900-5100 km | Liquid iron |
| Inner Core | 5100-6371 km | Solid iron |

## Crust Types:
- **Continental:** 30-70 km thick, less dense
- **Oceanic:** 5-10 km thick, more dense

## Mantle:
- Upper mantle: Asthenosphere (plastic)
- Lower mantle: Solid but flows slowly

## Core:
- Generates Earth's magnetic field
- Temperature: 5000-6000 C

slides.title: Plate Tectonics
slides.content:
# Plate Tectonics

## Theory:
- Earth's surface divided into plates
- Plates float on asthenosphere
- Move slowly (cm/year)

## Plate Boundaries:

| Type | Movement | Features |
|------|----------|----------|
| Divergent | Apart | Mid-ocean ridges, rift valleys |
| Convergent | Together | Mountains, trenches, volcanoes |
| Transform | Slide past | Earthquakes |

## Evidence:
- Continental fit (puzzle pieces)
- Fossil distribution
- Matching rock formations
- Seafloor spreading

## Driving Forces:
- Convection in mantle
- Ridge push
- Slab pull

slides.quizQuestion: Mountains form at which type of plate boundary?

slides.title: Minerals
slides.content:
# Minerals

## Definition:
- Naturally occurring
- Inorganic
- Solid
- Crystalline structure
- Definite chemical composition

## Properties:

| Property | Description |
|----------|------------|
| Hardness | Mohs scale (1-10) |
| Luster | Metallic, glassy, earthy |
| Color | Variable, not reliable |
| Streak | Powder color |
| Cleavage | How it breaks |

## Common Minerals:

| Mineral | Composition | Use |
|---------|-------------|-----|
| Quartz | SiO2 | Glass, electronics |
| Feldspar | Aluminosilicate | Ceramics |
| Calcite | CaCite | Cement |
| Mica | Silicate | Insulation |

slides.title: Rock Cycle
slides.content:
# Rock Cycle

## Three Rock Types:

### Igneous:
- From cooled magma/lava
- Intrusive (slow cooling, large crystals)
- Extrusive (fast cooling, small crystals)
- Examples: Granite, basalt

### Sedimentary:
- From deposited sediments
- Layers, fossils
- Examples: Sandstone, limestone, shale

### Metamorphic:
- Changed by heat and pressure
- New minerals form
- Examples: Marble (from limestone), slate (from shale)

## The Cycle:
```
Igneous -> Weathering -> Sediment
Sediment -> Compaction -> Sedimentary
Any rock + Heat/Pressure -> Metamorphic
Any rock + Melting -> Magma -> Igneous
```

slides.title: Earthquakes and Volcanoes
slides.content:
# Earthquakes and Volcanoes

## Earthquakes:

**Cause:** Sudden release of stress in rocks

**Terms:**
- Focus: Underground origin
- Epicenter: Surface above focus
- Seismic waves: P, S, surface waves

**Measurement:**
- Richter scale (magnitude)
- Mercalli scale (intensity)

## Volcanoes:

| Type | Shape | Eruption |
|------|-------|----------|
| Shield | Broad, flat | Gentle, lava flows |
| Cinder cone | Steep, small | Moderate |
| Composite | Tall, steep | Explosive |

**Volcanic Materials:**
- Lava, ash, pyroclastic flows
- Gases (H2O, CO2, SO2)

**Ring of Fire:**
- Pacific rim
- 75% of world's volcanoes

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Geology Summary

## Earth's Layers:
- Crust, Mantle, Outer Core, Inner Core

## Plate Tectonics:
| Boundary | Result |
|----------|--------|
| Divergent | Ridges, rifts |
| Convergent | Mountains, trenches |
| Transform | Earthquakes |

## Rock Types:
| Type | Formation |
|------|----------|
| Igneous | Cooled magma |
| Sedimentary | Deposited layers |
| Metamorphic | Heat/pressure |

## Natural Hazards:
- Earthquakes at plate boundaries
- Volcanoes at convergent/divergent

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Geology!
